4349.text: They're hearing it from community leaders.

4351.text:
I think that speaks to the importance of what
Liz and USGLC are doing here.

4357.text:
Less people will get up at my town halls and
say, “Cut off all the foreign aid.”

4362.text:
Frank Sesno: Senator Ayotte, Senator Kaine,
thank you both for your comments.

4369.text:
Thank you for your efforts to help build a
more secure and prosperous world.

4373.text:
Sen. Kaine: Frank, can I ask that you guys
thank one more group of people?

4377.text: Raj had all the USAID folks stand up.

4379.text:
Can anybody here who’s connected with the
Department of State stand up because I want

4383.text:
to make sure our diplomacy folks get some
love, too.

4385.text:
U.S. Department of State, we got a big group
over here.

4389.text:
Very dangerous places, top professionals,
they do wonderful work.

4395.text: Well, thank you very, very much.

4398.text:
Now, I'm going to turn it over to Retired
General Kip Ward.

4402.text:
He is a member of USGLC’s National Security
Advisory Council.

4406.text:
We’re going to sit in place for a minute
and then we’ll follow him off the stage.

4410.text:
Gen. Ward: Thank you, Frank, for that introduction
and to both Senators Ayotte and Kaine for

4416.text:
those enlightening conversations that you
just blessed us with.

4419.text:
I'd like to also extend my congratulations
to tonight honorees for this well-deserved

4424.text:
recognition of your critical contributions
in our national security and economic prosperity.

4429.text:
As we come to this conclusion of tonight’s
dinner, I'm proud to stand before you as a

4433.text:
member of the United States Global Coalition’s
National Security Advisory Council, a group

4440.text:
of 160 retired three and four-star general
and flag officers who are committed to ensure

4445.text:
that American’s interests are indeed represented
in our development and diplomacy efforts in

4450.text: order to keep our world safe.

4454.text: It's real and it's a big deal.

4456.text:
I also could not be more proud in over these
United States 30,000 veterans had joined in

4467.text:
our efforts, these young women and men have
served on the frontlines in our nation’s

4472.text:
wars experiencing first-hand the critical
role that their civilian partners play in

4477.text:
rebuilding societies after conflict and providing
humanitarian assistance after natural disasters,

4484.text:
and perhaps more importantly, the role that
they have in preventing conflict in the first

4491.text:
place and that’s so critically important
to those of us who now wear and have worn

4498.text:
Our military leaders and veterans who swore
to protect this country know what's at stake.

4507.text:
When we cut foreign aid, we put America's
security at risk.

4513.text:
At this time of holiday blessings, I'd like
to ask those who are veterans that are here

4522.text:
tonight to please stand and I would ask you
to join me in offering a round of applause

4527.text: to them for their service to our nation.

4537.text:
Now, to end our program, it gives me a great
honor to bring back to stage the uplifting

4551.text:
Amani Children’s Choir from Uganda, a choir
that I had a pleasure of seeing on one of

4556.text:
my many visits to the continent of Africa
as I was in Uganda.

4560.text:
Again, the uplifting Amani Children’s Choir
from Uganda.

4588.text:
[Choir singing 00:37:05 to 00:39:35]
Carolyn Miles: Thank you for having the Amani

4781.text:
to conclude our performance with a special
African song called, [foreign language 00:40:11].

4830.text:
Please join us as we celebrate moving forward
[for a change 00:40:15] and progress for the

4972.text:
I don’t know about you guys, but I am not
going to get over that rendition of America,

5032.text: the Beautiful for a long time.

5037.text:
Let me just say thank you to everyone who’s
here tonight.

5043.text:
I want to thank the choir and the chorus as
well.

5054.text:
I want to again, thank our honorees but let’s
continue our conversation.

5059.text:
Actually, dessert is going to be served across
the way in the Ambassador Ballroom, and while

5065.text:
there, there is a special photo booth to help
us share some holiday memories and those are

5073.text:
going to be sent actually to those who are
serving us overseas.

5077.text: We would love to have you take a photo.

5079.text: Thank you for a fantastic evening.
